channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: "子宫内膜异位症终于有了进展，真是令人兴奋"。@ItsRachelDobbs 向《The Intelligence》讲述子宫内膜异位症的药物研发工作
item.description:
“It’s really exciting that movement is finally happening on this disease.” @ItsRachelDobbs tells “The Intelligence” about work towards a drug for endometriosis https://t.co/iRqYk6nNxx pic.twitter.com/zzx4BiiRtH

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 英国有数十万个 "幽灵池塘"。只要一点水和灯光，它们就能复活 🐸
item.description:
Britain is haunted by hundreds of thousands of “ghost ponds”. With a little water and light, they can be summoned back to life https://t.co/EUPdU0uets 🐸

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 在本周的 @《经济学家》中，我写到了萦绕在英国的 "幽灵池塘"--它们能以惊人的速度复活
item.description:
For this week’s @TheEconomist I wrote about the “ghost ponds” that haunt Britain—and can be summoned back to life surprisingly quickly https://t.co/ZPs4KUd0lU

— Caitlin Talbot (@TalbotCaitlin) February 28, 2024

item.title: "中国认为，无论11月发生什么，都不会是赢家。"@jarmiles 向 "The Intelligence "讲述从北京看美国大选。收听播客 👇
item.description:
“China is thinking that whatever happens in November, it’s not going to be a winner.” @jarmiles tells “The Intelligence” how the American election looks from Beijing. Listen to the podcast https://t.co/UBoBLdYMIG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 将历史细分为列表是一种通俗易懂的方式。最古老的 "历史 "可能是世界七大奇迹，这是公元前 100-200 年的奇迹清单👇。
item.description:
Breaking down history into lists is appealingly accessible. The oldest “histicle” may be the seven wonders of the world, a list of marvels from 100-200BC https://t.co/ODKpbtPNzr 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 玛丽娜-勒庞的强硬右翼政党全国集会党向巴黎的当权者发起了魅力攻势。对于一个将自己描绘成人民的拥护者、反对脱离群众的统治阶级的政党来说，这种努力必然是棘手的👇。
item.description:
Marine Le Pen’s hard-right National Rally has launched a charm offensive on the Paris establishment.

For a party that portrays itself as the champion of the people against the out-of-touch ruling class, such efforts are necessarily tricky https://t.co/CyU7P4VOji 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 如何不制作 PowerPoint 幻灯片的示例 👇
item.description:
An example of how not to make a PowerPoint slide https://t.co/zQaUh2KpMP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 今天的 "智力 "节目：从北京看美国大选、子宫内膜异位症药物研发进展以及播客 20 年回顾。收听每日节目： 🎧
item.description:
Today on “The Intelligence”: the view of America’s election from Beijing, progress toward a drug for endometriosis, and a reflection on 20 years of podcasting. Listen to the daily show: https://t.co/SSrGBPmfwK 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: "詹姆斯-贝内特（James Bennet）写道："美国人可以尽情嚷嚷他们缺乏言论自由，但如果他们不学会重新倾听彼此的声音，他们将永远无法克服分歧，也无法解决任何真正的问题。
item.description:
“Americans can shout about their lack of free speech all they want, but they will never be able to overcome their differences, and deal with any of their real problems, if they do not learn to listen to each other again,” writes James Bennet https://t.co/54lNYhhhXL 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 在《达荷美》中，被掠夺的文物被归还给西非。今年的柏林电影节最高奖得主是一个及时的选择，因为各国面临着越来越大的压力，要求归还其帝国军队掠夺的文物 👇
item.description:
In “Dahomey”, plundered artefacts are returned to west Africa.

This year’s winner of the top prize at the Berlinale film festival is a timely choice, as countries face increasing pressure to repatriate objects seized by their imperial troops https://t.co/7XbjZ6427b 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 约有 1050 万人生活在中国境外，他们是或曾经是中国公民。但离开中国并不一定就能摆脱中国政权的控制👇。
item.description:
There are about 10.5m people living outside China who are, or once were, Chinese citizens. But leaving the country does not necessarily offer freedom from the regime’s structures https://t.co/pbeiDyzuGi 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 这十张图表比较了乔-拜登和唐纳德-特朗普的记录。谁更胜一筹？ 👇
item.description:
These ten charts compare Joe Biden’s record with Donald Trump’s. Who comes out better? https://t.co/i7SYZsh6aq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 巴勒斯坦权力机构将任命一位新总理，为加沙的 "新现实 "做准备。无论谁接任，都将面临三大障碍 👇
item.description:
The Palestinian Authority will name a new prime minister as it prepares for an “emerging reality” in Gaza. Whoever takes the reins will face three big obstacles https://t.co/RmfNuAFRc2 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 没有哪家公司能像英伟达（Nvidia）一样从人工智能的蓬勃发展中获益匪浅。自 2023 年 1 月以来，这家芯片制造商的股价飙升了近 450%。是什么让它的产品如此特别？我们来解释一下👇。
item.description:
No other firm has benefited from the boom in AI as much as Nvidia. Since January 2023 the chipmaker’s share price has surged by almost 450%.

What makes its products so special? We explain https://t.co/O2gaY3kqKr 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 哈尔科夫正在俄罗斯火箭弹的袭击下挣扎。一些已返回边境解放区的人又开始离开，尽管迄今为止人数不多。
item.description:
Kharkiv is struggling under Russian rocket attacks. Some who had returned to the liberated border region have begun to leave again, though so far the numbers are small.

Those who remain fear that life will never return to normal https://t.co/njpcnbD8SG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 在本周的 "Money Talks "播客中，@TomLeeDevlin、@Birdyword 和@alice_fulwood 提出了人工智能工具能否将教育带入数字时代的问题 👇。
item.description:
On this week’s “Money Talks” podcast, @TomLeeDevlin, @Birdyword and @alice_fulwood ask whether AI tools can bring education into the digital age https://t.co/dQim6u8BHJ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 生成式人工智能可以从根本上改变法律实践。如果它能在 20 秒内完成十几名律师每人需要 50 小时才能完成的任务，那么大型法律公司为什么还要继续聘用几十名律师呢？ 👇
item.description:
Generative AI could radically alter the practice of law. If it can do in 20 seconds a task that would have taken a dozen associates 50 hours each, then why would big legal firms continue hiring dozens of associates? https://t.co/FRN84JOLHX 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: EssilorLuxottica 希望成为智能眼镜领域的领导者。这个想法并不新鲜，但很多乐观主义者认为，智能眼镜的时代已经到来。第二个大想法更具个性化： 👇。
item.description:
EssilorLuxottica wants to be the leader in smart glasses. The idea is not new, but plenty of optimists think that the moment for smart spectacles has arrived. The second big idea is more personal: https://t.co/tz5noHw1V9 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 超过 60% 的法国人认为玛丽娜-勒庞的国民公署与其他政党无异。近三分之二的选民认为该党能够赢得选举。如果认为一旦它获胜，法国、欧洲或北约就能一如既往，那将是极其不明智的👇。
item.description:
Over 60% of the French see Marine Le Pen’s National Rally as a party like any other. Nearly two-thirds of voters think it can win office.

It would be extremely unwise to assume that, if it does, France, Europe or NATO could carry on as before https://t.co/OgXnbksJmS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 最新研究显示，全球最便宜的 20 座城市中有 9 座位于亚洲。但亚洲大陆也有一些世界上最昂贵的大都市👇。
item.description:
Nine of the world’s 20 cheapest cities are in Asia, according to new research. But the continent is also home to some of the world’s most exorbitant metropolises https://t.co/4opcedVYNV 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 前间谍是特别有实力的作家。这些是我们推荐的最佳间谍小说👇。
item.description:
Former spooks make especially strong authors. These are our recommendations for the best spy novels https://t.co/UVEecE7BaN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 大多数服用抗抑郁药物的人并不需要这种药物。找出真正需要抗抑郁药的人，并让其他人摆脱这种药物👇。
item.description:
Most people on antidepressants don’t need them. Identify those who really do—and wean other people off them https://t.co/xVNgPTj5ym 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 睡眠对人类健康至关重要。它占据了人一生中约三分之一的时间。然而，人们对它的了解却少得令人吃惊。一篇新论文试图填补一些空白 👇。
item.description:
Sleep is essential to human health. It takes up around one-third of people’s lives. And yet surprisingly little is known about it. A new paper attempts to fill some of the gaps https://t.co/JpquvahiaS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 五篇介绍如何简单而出色地写作的文章 👇
item.description:
Five texts that explain how to write simply and well https://t.co/cbQxF4H7f6 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 社会对我们狂轰滥炸，要求我们变得更快乐、更健康、更富有。为什么我们变得如此不满足于平凡？ 👇
item.description:
Society bombards us with instructions to be happier, fitter and richer. Why have we become so dissatisfied with being ordinary? https://t.co/GwLIYyUsvs 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 生命的 U 形弯曲--为何始于 46 👇?
item.description:
The U-bend of life—and why it begins at 46 https://t.co/c1ckUzdAnG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: 中层管理者常常被认为是懒惰的。事实上，他们有一个共同的问题👇。
item.description:
Middle managers are often presumed to be lazy. In fact, they are suffering from a common problem https://t.co/2xlW21mJFn 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 28, 2024

item.title: "我们不需要单独作战，也不需要单独防御。@Gottemoeller在我们的 "制衡 "播客中解释了为什么北约对美国很重要🎧。
item.description:
“We don’t need to fight alone, and we don’t need to defend alone.” @Gottemoeller explains why NATO is important to America, on our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/LJg8uf9NpJ 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 世界正在目睹一场前所未有的金融战争。但就在西方加紧制裁的同时，规避制裁的方法也变得越来越复杂👇。
item.description:
The world is witnessing an unprecedented surge in financial warfare. But just as the West ratchets up sanctions, ways to circumvent them are becoming more sophisticated https://t.co/o40TRWAhaO 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 硅谷新发现的清醒有很多值得庆祝的地方。初创企业不再不惜一切代价追求增长。创始人重新发现了节俭。假以时日，独角兽的时代可能不会被错过 🦄。
item.description:
There is plenty to celebrate in the newfound sobriety of Silicon Valley. Startups have stopped espousing growth at all costs. Founders have rediscovered frugality. Many are being cautious with hiring.

In time, the age of the unicorn may not be missed https://t.co/oJ3z5lYo85 🦄

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024
